title: Can I replace 'to the extent that' with 'if' in the sentence 'I am his companion - and guardian, to the extent that he will allow himself to be guarded.' without changing the subtle meaning of the sentence? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most of my points have already been mentioned by one or more of the other answers, but I will attempt to summarize. There is a problem with the meaning of the sentence. Guarding someone is not the job of a “companion” and not even of a “guardian”; it’s something a bodyguard does. Whether or not you use “to the extend that” or just a simple “if”, the sentence will not make sense for that reason.Replacing “to the extent that” with “if” will change the meaning of any sentence.“If” allows for only two possibilities (either he will allow himself to be guarded or he will not)“To the extent that”, on the other hand, allows for an infinite number of possibilities, i.e., all the various situations and conditions under which he may allow himself to be guarded, and the different “degrees” of guarding intensity (or closeness) that he may be willing to accept.

You’re correct in thinking that “if” and “to the extent that” are close in meaning but not exactly the same. In theory, “if” leaves open the question of whether he’ll accept a guardian at all, and “to the extent that” assumes he’ll accept a guardian in at least some small way. Most readers and listeners won’t give any thought to that distinction. There’s a third way of saying it that will work if you allow yourself to use a somewhat rare old word, “insofar.” “I am his companion and guardian, insofar as he will allow himself to be guarded.” It’s not the word most people would use but I think most people understand it.

No. You will change the semantic meaning of the sentence - and not subtly - and you’ll alter the grammatical construction resulting in an awkward sentence. I am his companion and guardian if he will allow himself to be guarded - is an awkward sentence. To the extent - cannot be replaced with if. If cannot be replaced with to the extent - and the example sentence is awkward as well. You're mixing tenses. I am his companion and guard to the extent that he allows himself to be guarded. I will be his companion and guard to the extent that he will allow himself to be guarded.

I personally would replace it with the conditional “should.” "I am his companion - and guardian, ‘should’ he allow himself to be guarded." You could pass it by with “if,” however for that sentence I would use “if only.” That would imply that it is not a common circumstance to have occur. And in that instance, I would be change “will" to “would.” "I am his companion - and guardian, ‘if only he would' allow himself to be guarded."

No. The whole point of using “to the extent that” is to emphasize proportionality: there are a range of possibilities from none through less through more through totally. Perhaps he will allow himself to be guarded when he goes to the restroom and not otherwise. Then you are his guardian to that extent. By contrast, “if” is binary: yes/no.

No, you can't. You might get closer to the meaning by saying “if and when he allows himself...” or “as much as he allows himself…” I do find “to the extent that…” to be a little awkward. On the other hand, it expresses what you want to say, so….

No. It would change the "subtle meaning". "To the extent that" is talking about how much he allows himself to be guarded. It might be a little or a lot, or anything in between. "If" would just mean he allows himself to be guarded, or he doesn’t.

No, I don’t think you can do that without changing the “subtle meaning”. “to the extent that…” implies that he will allow this but only up to a point. “if he will allow …” means either he will allow it, or he won’t allow it.
In this sentence, I would say they mean almost the same thing. “If” implies that maybe he won’t allow it. “To the extent that” means he might allow it a little bit but not completely.

There is no “subtle meaning” of the sentence. In fact, there is no meaning at all. A “guardian’ is not literally ‘one who guards another.’ So whether you say ‘to the extent that’ or ‘if,’ the sentence will still be nonsense.
